Fe3O4 nanoparticles with core size of 3.6 nm were synthesized according to a previous report with slight modifications.[2] Typically, 1.41 g (4 mmol) of Fe(acac)3, 3.39 g (12 mmol) of oleic acid, 3.21 g (12 mmol) of oleylamine, and 2.70 g (10 mmol) of 1-octadecanol were dissolved in 40 mL of diphenyl ether. After being purged with nitrogen for 30 min, the solution was refluxed for 30 min under stirring.
Then the reaction system was cooled to room temperature. The resultant nanoparticles were precipitated by ethanol, collected by centrifugation, washed with ethanol for three times, and finally redispersed in THF or cyclohexane for further experiments.
As a typical example, 150 mg of PEG derivative was dissolved in 10 mL of THF containing 10 mg hydrophobic Fe3O4 nanoparticles. Then, the reaction mixture was heated to 60 C and kept at this temperature for 12 h under stirring. After that, the Fe3O4 nanoparticles were precipitated by cyclohexane, washed with cyclohexane for three times, and then dried under vacuum at room temperature. The particle powders obtained, independent of the anchoring group of PEG derivatives and the particle core size, were found to be readily dissolved in water, supporting that the PEG coating was effectively realized. To remove excess PEG ligand, the resultant aqueous solutions containing the PEGylated Fe3O4 nanoparticles were purified by ultrafiltration for 4 cycles using 100 kDa MWCO centrifugal filter (Millipore YM-100).

Fe3O4 nanoparticles with core size of 10.9 nm were also synthesized according to a previous report.[1] In brief, 3.6 g (4 mmol) of freshly prepared iron oleate and 3.39 g (4 mmol) of oleic acid were dissolved in 25 mL of 1-octadecene. The resultant solution was heated to 310 C by a rate of 3.3 C/min, and then maintained at 310 C for 30 min under nitrogen protection. The preparation was terminated by cooling the reaction mixture down to room temperature. Following the procedures described above, 10.9 nm Fe3O4 nanoparticles were obtained. As a typical example, 150 mg of PEG derivative was dissolved in 10 mL of THF containing 10 mg hydrophobic Fe3O4 nanoparticles. Then, the reaction mixture was heated to 60 C and kept at this temperature for 12 h under stirring. After that, the Fe3O4 nanoparticles were precipitated by cyclohexane, washed with cyclohexane for three times, and then dried under vacuum at room temperature. The particle powders obtained, independent of the anchoring group of PEG derivatives and the particle core size, were found to be readily dissolved in water, supporting that the PEG coating was effectively realized. To remove excess PEG ligand, the resultant aqueous solutions containing the PEGylated Fe3O4 nanoparticles were purified by ultrafiltration for 4 cycles using 100 kDa MWCO centrifugal filter (Millipore YM-100).

To obtain 9 nm Fe3O4 MNS, 18 g of iron oleate complex and 2.35 g of oleic acid were 
dissolved in the 100 g of octadecene. The reaction mixture was stirred for 10 min under 
nitrogen atmosphere. The mixture was then heated to 320 °C and kept for 25 min. The 
mixture was then cooled down to room temperature, and ethanol was added to precipitate 
the MNS. 10 mg (in hexane) and 200 mg of TMA-POSS (in 1 ml water) were mixed. This reaction 
mixture was purged with nitrogen, capped, and stirred vigorously for 48 h which transfers 
particles from organic phase to the aqueous phase. The layers were carefully separated, and 
dialyzed against deionized/distilled water (24 h) to remove free POSS (Carroll et al. 2004; 
Frankamp et al. 2006)

To obtain 9 nm Fe3O4 MNS, 18 g of iron oleate complex and 2.35 g of oleic acid were 
dissolved in the 100 g of octadecene. The reaction mixture was stirred for 10 min under 
nitrogen atmosphere. The mixture was then heated to 320 °C and kept for 25 min. The 
mixture was then cooled down to room temperature, and ethanol was added to precipitate 
the MNS. 9-nm Fe3O4 MNS were coated with 5, 10, and 13 nm thickness of silica shell by base￾catalyzed silica formation from tetraorthosilicate in water in oil emulsion. Typically, 1 ml of 
Igepal CO-520 was mixed with cyclohexane under vigorous stirring conditions. Fe3O4 MNS 
were dispersed in cyclohexane at a concentration of 1.25 mg/mL and then 2 ml were added 
slowly into the cyclohexane/Igepal solution followed by drop wise addition of 140 μl of 30 
% ammonium hydroxide. The resulting mixture stirred well for 40 min. For thickness of 5 
nm silica shell, 90 μl of TEOS while for 10 and 13 nm of shell thickness 270 μl of TEOS 
added to the above mixture. For 5 and 10 nm silica shell thickness, reaction mixture was 
stirred for 2 days while for 13 nm shell thickness, reaction mixture was stirred for 4 days. 
The precipitate with ethanol was collected by centrifugation at10,000 rpmandparticleswere 
washedseveral timesby redispersing in ethanol. Washed precipitate was dispersed in 
deionized water (Schultz-sikma et al. 2011).

The iron oxide cores were synthesis by thermo-decomposition of iron tri(acetyl acetonate) in the presence of oleic acid and oleylamine using a protocol modified according to a previous publication (see methods).4 The core size was controlled by varying the ratio between oleic acid/ oleylamine and the reaction temperature. The synthesized iron cores were photographed with TEM (Figure S1). The size distribution of the iron oxide cores were measured using an image processing software, ImagePro Plus. The two types of iron oxide cores used in this study were measured to be 4.8±0.9 nm and 13.8±2.2 nm in diameter, which are referred to as 5 nm and 14 nm, respectively. Given that the density of Fe3O4 is 5.17 g/cm3, the weight of a 4.8 nm core is 2.99×10-19 g and contains 2329 iron atoms. Likewise, a 13.8 nm core contains 55352 iron atoms. The molar concentration of the SPIOs was estimated by the molar concentration of iron divided by the number of iron atoms per SPIO. Functionalization of SPIOs can be achieved by mixing DSPE-mPEG and DSPE-PEG ended with functional groups at desired ratio before coating. Here the 14 nm SPIOs with amino groups were prepared by coating iron oxide cores with a mixture of DSPE-mPEG and DSPE-PEG-NH2. The percentage of DSPE-PEG-NH2 in the mixture was 10%, 20%, 50% or 100%. To increase the accessibility of functional groups for chemical conjugation, each functionalized DSPE-PEG2000 has twice more PEG units than that of a DSPE-mPEG1000 in the mixture. After coating and purification, the concentration of NH2 group in the final solution was measured by fluorescamine method. In brief, fluorescamine was dissolved in acetone at 0.3% (w/v). The SPIOs was dispersed in deionized water at 100 μg Fe/ml. The fluorescamine was mixed with the SPIO solutions in a 96-well quartz plate. The mixture was incubated at room temperature for 20 minutes. The standard solutions contained DSPE- PEG-amine and 100 μg Fe/ml of the SPIOs coated with DSPE-mPEG1000 alone. The fluorescence intensity was quantified with a microplate reader (ex: 395 nm, em: 470 nm). The number of amino groups per SPIO was estimated by dividing the molar concentration of amino groups with that of the SPIOs. As shown in Figure S5, our measurements indicated that the number of functionalized DSPE- PEG per nanoparticle was proportional to the initial DSPE-PEG loading ratio and the maximum number of NH2 groups on each 14 nm SPIO is approximately 600.

A 20 mL amount of PAA (Mw = 1800) solution (0.4−5.0 mg/mL) was first purged with nitrogen (≥50 min) for removal of oxygen. The polymer solution was then heated to reflux (100 °C). After that, 0.4 mL of iron precursor solution (50−500 mM FeCl3 plus 25−500 mM FeSO4) was quickly injected into the heated polymer solution, followed by addition of 6.0 mL of ammonia solution (2.8−28%). The reaction was kept at 100 °C under magnetic stirring. After 1.0 h, the solutions were cooled to room temperature. The obtained ES-MION1−7 were dialyzed (Mw cutoff 6−8 kDa) for 5 days in ultrapure water, which was changed every day. The dialyzed ES-MION1−7 were then concentrated by centrifugal ultrafiltration (Millipore, molecular size cutoff of 10 kDa). The Fe concentrations of the ES-MION1−7 solutions were determined by ICP-OES (Agilent 5100). The recovery of the ES-MION1−7 was calculated from the molar ratio of Fe in the obtained ES-MIONs to that in the feeding materials.

The dialyzed ES-MION1−7 were then concentrated by centrifugal ultrafiltration (Millipore, molecular size cutoff of 10 kDa). The Fe concentrations of the ES-MION1−7 solutions were determined by ICP-OES (Agilent 5100). The recovery of the ES-MION1−7 was calculated from the molar ratio of Fe in the obtained ES-MIONs to that in the feeding materials.

A 20 mL amount of PAA (Mw = 1800) solution (0.4−5.0 mg/mL) was first purged with nitrogen (≥50 min) for removal of oxygen. The polymer solution was then heated to reflux (100 °C). After that, 0.4 mL of iron precursor solution (50−500 mM FeCl3 plus 25−500 mM FeSO4) was quickly injected into the heated polymer solution, followed by addition of 6.0 mL of ammonia solution (2.8−28%). The reaction was kept at 100 °C under magnetic stirring. After 1.0 h, the solutions were cooled to room temperature. The obtained ES-MION1−7 were dialyzed (Mw cutoff 6−8 kDa) for 5 days in ultrapure water, which was changed every day. The dialyzed ES-MION1−7 were then concentrated by centrifugal ultrafiltration (Millipore, molecular size cutoff of 10 kDa). The Fe concentrations of the ES-MION1−7 solutions were determined by ICP-OES (Agilent 5100). The recovery of the ES-MION1−7 was calculated from the molar ratio of Fe in the obtained ES-MIONs to that in the feeding materials.

A 20 mL amount of PAA (Mw = 1800) solution (4 mg/mL) was first purged with nitrogen (≥50 min) for removal of oxygen. The polymer solution was then heated to reflux (100 °C) under magnetic stirring. After that, 0.4 mL of iron precursor solution (1.0 M FeCl3 plus 0.5 M FeSO4) was quickly injected into the heated polymer solution, followed by addition of 9.0 mL of ammonia solution (28%). The reaction was continued 1.0 h to obtain ES-MION8, or after 15 min of reaction, 0.6 mL of the iron precursor solution and 4.0 mL of the ammonia solution were injected followed by a further 45 min of reaction to obtain ES-MION9, or after both 15 and 30 min of reaction, 0.6 mL of the iron precursor solution and 4.0 mL of the ammonia solution were injected twice followed by a further 30 min of reaction to obtain ES-MION10.
The obtained ES-MION8−10 solutions were cooled to room temperature and then dialyzed (Mw cutoff 12−14 kDa) for 5 days in ultrapure water that was changed every day. The dialyzed ES- MION8−10 were then concentrated by centrifugal ultrafiltration (Millipore, molecular size cutoff of 10 kDa). The Fe concentrations of the ES-MION solutions were measured by ICP-OES. The recovery of the ES-MION8−10 was calculated from the molar ratio of Fe in the obtained ES-MIONs to that in the feeding materials.

The synthesis of Mn3O4 nanocubes with a side length of 12 nm was carried out according to a modification of a literature method.46 Briefly, 1 mmol of manganese(II) acetate, 0.67 g of oleylamine (OAm), and 0.12 g of oleic acid (OA) were dissolved in 8 mL of xylene under air. Then the solution was stirred and slowly heated to 90 °C before 1 mL of deionized water was injected into the solution. The resulting solution was maintained at 90 °C for 1.5 h. For the synthesis of Mn3O4 nanocubes with a side length of 19 nm, 15 mL of xylene was used instead of 8 mL of xylene. For the synthesis of Mn3O4 nanocubes with asidelengthof8nm,1.34gofOAmand0.25gofOAwereused instead of 0.67 g of OAm and 0.12 g of OA. A suspension (16 mL) of as-prepared Mn3O4 nanocubes in a 100 mL round-bottom flask was heated to 90 °C and vigorously stirred. Then 1 mL of 2.4 M aqueous iron(II) chloride tetrahydrate was injected. The resulting solution was maintained at 90 °C for 1.5 h. After cooled to room temperature, 20 mL of ethanol was added to precipitate HPIOs, which were washed three times with ethanol. As-prepared hollow porous γ-Fe2O3 nanoboxes were well-dispersed in nonpolar solvents such as n-hexane, chloroform, and toluene.

Synthesis of IO-11 was carried out as follows: 0.909 g (1 mmol) of iron oleate complex and 159 μL (0.5 mmol) of OA were dissolved in 15 mL of 1- octadecene (ODE) at room temperature. The resulting solution was degassed for 30 min at 100 °C, and then heated to 320 °C for 3 h under a nitrogen atmosphere. After cooling to room temperature, the product was precipitated with 25 mL of hexane and 25 mL of ethanol, and washed three times with ethanol. The product was dispersed and stored in n-hexane. For synthesis of IO-17 or IO-26, 12 or 8 mL of ODE was used instead of 15 mL of ODE, respectively.

For synthesis of IO-17 or IO-26, 12 or 8 mL of ODE was used instead of 15 mL of ODE, respectively.

The iron oleate-oleylamine complex was produced using a published procedure with slight modifications.1 Specifically, Fe(III) chloride (4.3 g) were reacted with the sodium oleate (24.5 g) and oleylamine (12 mL) in a solvent mixture (hexane-140 mL, ethanol-80 mL, and water-60 mL) at 70 oC for four hours. After phase separation, the aqueous phase was drained off and the organic phase containing the precursor was washed with DI water and left to dry in a vacuum chamber overnight.
Synthesis of iron oxide nanowhiskers. Iron oxide nanowhiskers were synthesized by heating the iron oleate-oleylamine complex (1.8 g) in 1-octadecene (13 mL) at 150 oC in the presence of capping ligands (0.1 OA mL/0.2 g TOPO). The reaction was kept at the reaction temperature for 2.5 hours under an argon atmosphere.

A straight- forward synthetic route to IOP-8.8 is as follows: 0.9 g (1 mmol) of iron oleate complex was dissolved in 10 mL of benzyl ether, with the addition of 0.16 mL (0.5 mmol) of oleic acid and 15 mg (0.05 mmol) of sodium oleate. The solution was kept at 120 C for 20 min before reaching reflux and was allowed to react for 1 h before cooling to room temperature. The products were obtained by addition of 50 mL of ethanol and centrifugation at 7000 rpm for 10 min. After being washed with ethanol twice, the precipitate was dispersed in hexane and stored for further use. The preparation of IOP-4.8 and IOP-2.8 is similar to the above procedure except for the quantity of sodium oleate (0.1 and 0.2 mmol, respectively).

In a typical experiment, 2 mL of iron oxide nanoplates (0.6 mg/mL) was added with 1.2 mL of Co-520, 0.2 mL of tetraethyl orthosilicate, 0.4 mL of ammonia, and 20 mL of cyclohexane. After being stirred for 16 h at room tempera- ture, the solution was mixed with 40 mL of ethanol and washed three times by centrifugation (14 000 rpm, 15 min). The silica- coated nanoplates (IOP@SiO2) were dissolved in ultrapure water and stored at 4 C.

The preparation of IOP-4.8 and IOP-2.8 is similar to the above procedure except for the quantity of sodium oleate (0.1 and 0.2 mmol, respectively).
For the preparation of stPEI-coated nanoplates, 5 mg of stPEI was mixed with the as-prepared IO- 4.8 (10 mg) in chloroform (2 mL). The organic solution was slowly added into ultrapure water (4 mL) under vigorous soni- cation, and the mixture was further shaken overnight to obtain transparent solution. The residual chloroform was removed by rotary evaporation, and the final aqueous solution was stored at 4 C for further use.

A straight- forward synthetic route to IOP-8.8 is as follows: 0.9 g (1 mmol) of iron oleate complex was dissolved in 10 mL of benzyl ether, with the addition of 0.16 mL (0.5 mmol) of oleic acid and 15 mg (0.05 mmol) of sodium oleate. The solution was kept at 120 C for 20 min before reaching reflux and was allowed to react for 1 h before cooling to room temperature. The products were obtained by addition of 50 mL of ethanol and centrifugation at 7000 rpm for 10 min. After being washed with ethanol twice, the precipitate was dispersed in hexane and stored for further use. The preparation of IOP-4.8 and IOP-2.8 is similar to the above procedure except for the quantity of sodium oleate (0.1 and 0.2 mmol, respectively).
The preparation of DMSA-coated nanoparticles was carried out through a ligand exchange process.7 For example, excess DMSA (10 mg) was dissolved in 10 mL of ultrapure water in a three-neck flask, and the as- prepared iron oxide nanoparticles (100 μmol) dissolved in hexane were added to the flask. The solution was then heated to reflux for 2 h before cooling to room temperature. The nanoparticles were obtained at down-layer, suggesting the successful DMSA coating. The obtained water-soluble nanopar- ticles were stored at 4 C.

In a typical synthesis process of MnIO cubes with a Fe/Mn ratio
of 5 : 1, iron oleate (0.65 g, 0.72 mmol), Mn-oleate (0.15 g, 0.24 mmol), NaCl (8 mg, 0.14 mmol), oleic acid (120 mL,
0.37 mmol), and distilled water (60 mL) were mixed together
with 10 mL of 1-octadecene. After this the reaction solution was
heated to reflux and kept at that temperature for 2 h, the
solution was cooled down to room temperature and mixed with
30 mL of isopropanol to precipitate the nanoparticles. The final
product was dispersed in hexane for further use. The prepara￾tion of MnIO cubes with Fe/Mn ratios of 12 : 1 and 22 : 1 is
similar to the aforementioned procedure except for the quantity
of Mn-oleate (0.1 g for 12 : 1 and 0.05 g for 22 : 1) and NaCl
(7 mg for 12 : 1 and 6.5 mg for 22 : 1).

of Mn-oleate (0.1 g for 12 : 1 and 0.05 g for 22 : 1) and NaCl
(7 mg for 12 : 1 and 6.5 mg for 22 : 1).

In a typical synthesis of IO octapods, iron oleate (0.8 g, 0.86 mmol), NaCl (10 mg, 0.17 mmol), oleic acid (110 L, 0.35 mmol), and distilled water (60 L) were mixed together with 10 mL of 1-octadecene. The resulting solution was degassed in vacuum for 30 min and backfilled with argon to remove any low volatile impurities and oxygen at room temperature. After that the reaction solution was heated to 320 °C with a constant
heating rate of 3.3 °C min-1, and kept at the temperature for 1 h. Then the solution was cooled to room temperature and mixed with 30 mL of isopropanol to precipitate the nanoparticles. The nanoparticles were separated by centrifugation and washed 3 times with ethanol. The final product was dissolved in hexane for long-term storage at 4 °C.

In a typical synthesis of ~5 nm NaDyF4 nanoparticles, 1 mmol of DyCl3.6H2O was added to a mixture of 4 ml oleic acid and 15 ml 1-octadecene, and heated to 120 °C under vacuum for 3 h. The solution was brought back to room temperature and a solution of 2 mmol NaOH and 2.5 mmol NH4F dissolved in 10 ml methanol was added. The resulting mixture was further stirred for 1 h at room temperature and then slowly heated to 70 °C to remove methanol. Once methanol was removed, the clear solution heated to 285 °C quickly (~ 15 °C/min) under argon blanket and kept stirred for 1 h. Subsequently, the solution was cooled down to room temperature and precipitated with ethanol. The nanoparticles were then washed several times with ethanol and collected by centrifugation (4500 rpm, Beckman Coulter Spinchron 15-rotor F0630). The washed nanoparticles were dispersed in 8 ml chloroform for further characterization and surface modification. ~10 and ~20 nm NaDyF4 nanoparticles were synthesized in similar method but with small changes in ligand concentration (oleic acid). 
Synthesized PMAO-PEG (100 mg) was dissolved in 9 ml chloroform. NaDyF4 nanoparticles dispersion in chloroform (1 ml) was added to it and the solution was stirred overnight at room temperature. Then, chloroform was removed slowly using a rotary evaporator (LABOROTO 4000, Heidolph, Germany) at room temperature leaving a waxy layer in the flask. About 15 ml of distilled water was then added to the waxy liquid and dispersed very well by sonication for 15 min. The flask was mounted back to the rotary evaporator and removed the remaining chloroform. The nanoparticles were then collected using an ultra-centrifuge (Optima XL- 100K, Beckman Coulter) at a speed of 50,000 rpm (171,000 g) for 1 h. The collected pellet was redispersed in 10 ml distilled water. The final nanoparticles dispersion in water was used for relaxivity measurements and phantom imaging.

Then, chloroform was removed slowly using a rotary evaporator (LABOROTO 4000, Heidolph, Germany) at room temperature leaving a waxy layer in the flask. About 15 ml of distilled water was then added to the waxy liquid and dispersed very well by sonication for 15 min. The flask was mounted back to the rotary evaporator and removed the remaining chloroform. The nanoparticles were then collected using an ultra-centrifuge (Optima XL- 100K, Beckman Coulter) at a speed of 50,000 rpm (171,000 g) for 1 h. The collected pellet was redispersed in 10 ml distilled water. The final nanoparticles dispersion in water was used for relaxivity measurements and phantom imaging.

In a typical synthesis of 2 mmol 3 nm-NaHoF4 NPs, 2 mmol of HoCl3$6H2O were dissolved in 100 mL flask containing 2 mL deionized water, 8 mL oleic acid and 30 mL 1-octadecene were then added into flask and mixed for 1 h at room temperature. Then the mixture was slowly heated to 120 C to get rid of water under argon atmosphere and maintained at 160 C for another 1 h, and then brought back to room temperature and 10 mL methanol solution dissolving 5 mmol NaOH and 8 mmol NH4F was added. The mixture was further stirred at room temperature for 3 h. After the evapo- ration of methanol at 80 C, the solution was slowly heated to 230 C and maintained for 15 min, then cooled down to room temperature. The product was washed with ethanol several times and finally dispersed in20 mL chloroform.~8, ~13 and ~29 nm- NaHoF4 nanoparticles were synthesized by similar method but with small changes of ligand concentration, temperature and time as summarized in Table S1. 

For good biocompatibility, the commercially available DSPE- PEG5k was used for surface modification of hydrophobic NaHoF4 NPs according to previously reported method with slight modifi- cations [25]. Typically, 5 mL of NaHoF4 solution in chloroform was added into 5 mL DSPE-PEG5k solution in chloroform (20 mg/mL) and then stirred for 15 min. The mixture was incubated at 60 C under vacuum in a rotary evaporator for 1 h to evaporate the sol- vent. Subsequently, 5 mL of water was added and then sonicated for 5 min to obtain the PEG-NaHoF4 NPs.

A high- temperature synthesis has been used to prepare NaHoF4 nanoparticles in a mixture of oleic acid and octadecene following established protocols with minor modifications.43−45 In a typical synthesis of NaHoF4 nanoparticles, a mixture of 1 mmol HoCl3·6H2O, 2.5 mL of oleic acid (OA), and 7.5 mL of 1-octadecene (ODE) were added to a 50 mL three-necked flask. The mixture was heated to 135 °C while stirring under vacuum and kept at this temperature about 30 min to form a clear Ho3+-oleate solution. After the oleate solution was cooled down to room temperature, a clear methanol solution (7.5 mL) containing 2.5 mmol NaOH and 4 mmol NH4F was added dropwise into the flask and kept stirring for at least 2 h under air condition. Then the solution was slowly heated to 70 °C to remove methanol. Under argon atmosphere, the solution was quickly heated from 70 to 305 °C (20 °C/min) and maintained at this temperature for 60 min and then cooled down to room temperature. Next, the NaHoF4 nanoparticles were precipitated with adding ethanol (∼35 mL) and centrifuged for 5 min at 5000 rpm (g-force = 2683). The supernatant was poured away and the washing process was repeated three times. Finally, the nanoparticles were dispersed in 10 mL of hexane for storing. We prepared NaHoF4 nanoparticles with different shapes (hexagonal prism, spherical-, and rod-like) and sizes (9−40 nm) by modulating the volume of OA and ODE, heating temperature and time (as shown in the Supporting Information).
The synthesis of NaDyF4 nanoparticles was similar to that of NaHoF4 nanoparticles, the main difference was that the Dy3+-oleate solution was formed at 140 °C for 30 min under vacuum, and the mixed solution was heated at 306 °C for 90 min under argon atmosphere. The shape and size of NaDyF4 nanoparticles were modulated by changing contents of NaOH and NH4F with 1.5 mL OA and 7.5 mL ODE (as detailed in the Supporting Information). 
(1,2-Distearoyl-sn- glycero-3-phosphoethanolamine-N-[methoxy(polyethylene glycol)- 2000] (ammonium salt)). The commercial DSPE-mPEG2000 was used to modify the surface of NaHoF4 nanoparticles according to a reported method with a slight modification.47 Typical example: To coat 10 mg of NaHoF4 nanoparticles, about 0.5 mL solution (20 mg/ mL) was used and hexane was removed under argon flow and followed by adding 0.5 mL chloroform. About 10 mg of DSPE-mPEG2000 was dissolved in 1.5 mL of chloroform. The two chloroform solutions were mixed together and shaken for 15 min in a shaker. Then 4 mL of DMSO (dimethyl sulfoxide) was added slowly to the mixture and shaken in a shaker for 30 min. Chloroform was removed by vaporization under vacuum. After that, 15 mL of deionized water was added slowly to the colloidal solution in DMSO. DMSO was substituted with deionized water by centrifuging in special centrifugal filter tubes (Vivaspin Turbo 15 100 kDa cutoff size) 3 times with water. NaHoF4 nanoparticles coated with DSPE-mPEG2000 were dissolved in 1 mL of deionized water at last.

(The amphiphilic PMAO−PEG (poly(maleic anhydride-alt-1-octadecene)−polyethylene glycol) polymer was prepared by ourselves27 according to the protocol developed by Yu et al.46 Typical example of NaDyF4 coating: First, 10 mg of NaDyF4 nanoparticles was dispersed in 1 mL of chloroform solution and about 10 mg of PMAO−PEG polymer was dissolved in 1 mL of chloroform, and then the mixed solution was added into a flask and shaken for about 30 min. Second, the chloroform was completely removed by a rotary evaporator for 30 min and a thin layer was left on the wall of the flask. Third, about 15 mL of deionized water was added to the flask and sonicated for about 5 min to form a cloudy solution. Finally, the cloudy solution was filtered with a 0.45 μm filter and a clear water solution of NaDyF4 coated with PMAO−PEG was obtained.

Then the solution was slowly heated to 70 °C to remove methanol. Next, the NaHoF4 nanoparticles were precipitated with adding ethanol (∼35 mL) and centrifuged for 5 min at 5000 rpm (g-force = 2683). The supernatant was poured away and the washing process was repeated three times. Finally, the nanoparticles were dispersed in 10 mL of hexane for storing. We prepared NaHoF4 nanoparticles with different shapes (hexagonal prism, spherical-, and rod-like) and sizes (9−40 nm) by modulating the volume of OA and ODE, heating temperature and time (as shown in the Supporting Information).
The synthesis of NaDyF4 nanoparticles was similar to that of NaHoF4 nanoparticles, the main difference was that the Dy3+-oleate solution was formed at 140 °C for 30 min under vacuum, and the mixed solution was heated at 306 °C for 90 min under argon atmosphere. The shape and size of NaDyF4 nanoparticles were modulated by changing contents of NaOH and NH4F with 1.5 mL OA and 7.5 mL ODE (as detailed in the Supporting Information). 
(The amphiphilic PMAO−PEG (poly(maleic anhydride-alt-1-octadecene)−polyethylene glycol) polymer was prepared by ourselves27 according to the protocol developed by Yu et al.46 Typical example of NaDyF4 coating: First, 10 mg of NaDyF4 nanoparticles was dispersed in 1 mL of chloroform solution and about 10 mg of PMAO−PEG polymer was dissolved in 1 mL of chloroform, and then the mixed solution was added into a flask and shaken for about 30 min. Second, the chloroform was completely removed by a rotary evaporator for 30 min and a thin layer was left on the wall of the flask. Third, about 15 mL of deionized water was added to the flask and sonicated for about 5 min to form a cloudy solution. Finally, the cloudy solution was filtered with a 0.45 μm filter and a clear water solution of NaDyF4 coated with PMAO−PEG was obtained.

Under argon condition, Pt(acac)2 (197 mg, 0.5 mmol), 1, 2- hexadecanediol (390 mg, 1.5 mmol), and dioctyl ether (20 mL) were mixed and heated to 100 oC. Oleic acid (0.16 mL, 0.5 mmol), oleylamine (0.17 mL, 0.5 mmol) were added, After ~5 min, when the color of solution was changed from yellow to brown, Fe(CO)5 (0.13 mL, 1 mmol) was added immediately, then the mixture was heated to reflux (297 oC). The reaction was cooled down to the room temperature after 1 hour. The addition of ethanol (30 mL) to the reaction mixture afforded a black product by centrifuging. The FePt nanoparticles were dispersed in hexane and stored in nitrogen.

Under inert atmosphere, 20 mL of 1- octadecene containing 0.15 mL of oleylamine and ~20 mg of as-prepared FePt nanoparticles were heated at 120 oC for 30 min. 0.35 mL of Fe(CO)5 was injected into the hot solution, then the solution was kept at 180 oC for 20 min. Without any centrifugation and purification, the dispersion of the mixture (FePt@Fe core-shell intermediate) was moved to ambient atmosphere and heated up to 180 oC with O2 gas flow at rate of ~2 m3/h for about 2 hours. The Fe nanoshells were completely oxidized to produce Fe2O3 nanoshells by Kirkendall effect during the oxidization. After cooling to the room temperature, the addition of isopropanol (30 mL) to the reaction mixture afforded a brown product by centrifuging. The product was further washed by hexane (5 mL) and ethanol (20 mL) two times. Finally, the FePt@Fe2O3 yolk-shell nanoparticles were dispersed in hexane. (Caution: the oxidation reaction should be carried out in small scale (< 10 mL) since the large scale synthesis may cause a fire.)

The rod-shaped FeOOH nanostructure was prepared by hydro- lysis of FeCl3 aqueous solution. In a typical synthesis of 70 nm length FeOOH NRs, 20 mmol of FeCl3·6H2O was added into a round-bottom flask containing 100 ml of deionized water with 0.2 ml polyethyleneimine (PEI). The reaction mixture was heated at 80 °C under magnetic stirring for 2 h to obtain a uniform rod-shaped FeOOH nanostructure. The precipitate was separated by centrifugation and washed several times with deionized water and ethanol. The length of NRs is controlled from 25 to 70 nm by varying the PEI content to be 2, 1.5, 1, 0.5, 0.3 and 0.2 ml. Further, a decrease of PEI content to 0.1 ml and below transformed the rod-shape morphology of FeOOH to a spindle shaped structure of length above 100 nm.
Fe3O4 NRs were synthesized as follows: 500 mg of FeOOH nanorods and 25 mmol of oleylamine were taken in a three necked round bottom flask. Under a nitrogen atmosphere, the solution was heated to 200 °C for 4 h. The final product was subjected to magnetic separation and washed with a mixture of hexane and acetone several times to remove any uncoordi- nated amine molecules. The details of the synthesis approach are depicted in Scheme 1. The morphology of NRs was retained even after the reduction at 200 °C.

Uniform Fe3O4 nanoparticles (σ ≤ 15%) were prepared using our previously published protocol.32 In a typical synthesis of 6 nm Fe3O4 nanoparticles, a mixture of 5 mM of FeCl2 and 25 mM of oleylamine (amine to precursor molar ratio of 5 : 1) was heated at 200 °C under an N2 atmosphere. The size was controlled with a molar ratio of the precursor to amine of 1 : 3 (9 nm) and 1 : 7 (4 nm), respectively. To further increase the particle size above 9 nm, a seed-mediated growth model was utilized.33 For example, the smaller nanoparticles of 6 nm were first mixed (in a different quantity of 100 mg or 150 mg) with more precursor materials and the mixture was heated as per the above procedure to achieve 12 nm and 16 nm Fe3O4 nanoparticles, respectively.

To use these samples as MRI contrast agents, the as prepared Fe3O4 NRs were subjected to surface modification with poly- ethyleneimine (using the ligand exchange approach as depicted in Fig. S1†). 100 mg of the as prepared Fe3O4 NRs were dispersed in 10 mL of toluene and mixed with 10 ml of dimethylformamide (DMF) containing 2 ml of PEI. Under an N2 atmosphere, the mixture was then continuously stirred at 80 °C for 8 h. After the reaction, the final product was sub- jected to magnetic separation and washed with ethanol several times to remove uncoordinated PEI molecules. The functiona- lized nanorods were dispersed in deionized water and taken for phantom MRI imaging. Similarly to NRs, the aqueous sus- pension of the amine coated nanoparticles is also prepared by surface modification with polyethyleneimine (PEI).

Uniform Fe3O4 nanoparticles (σ ≤ 15%) were prepared using our previously published protocol.32 In a typical synthesis of 6 nm Fe3O4 nanoparticles, a mixture of 5 mM of FeCl2 and 25 mM of oleylamine (amine to precursor molar ratio of 5 : 1) was heated at 200 °C under an N2 atmosphere. The size was controlled with a molar ratio of the precursor to amine of 1 : 3 (9 nm) and 1 : 7 (4 nm), respectively. To further increase the particle size above 9 nm, a seed-mediated growth model was utilized.33 For example, the smaller nanoparticles of 6 nm were first mixed (in a different quantity of 100 mg or 150 mg) with more precursor materials and the mixture was heated as per the above procedure to achieve 12 nm and 16 nm Fe3O4 nanoparticles, respectively.

To use these samples as MRI contrast agents, the as prepared Fe3O4 NRs were subjected to surface modification with poly- ethyleneimine (using the ligand exchange approach as depicted in Fig. S1†). 100 mg of the as prepared Fe3O4 NRs were dispersed in 10 mL of toluene and mixed with 10 ml of dimethylformamide (DMF) containing 2 ml of PEI. Under an N2 atmosphere, the mixture was then continuously stirred at 80 °C for 8 h. After the reaction, the final product was sub- jected to magnetic separation and washed with ethanol several times to remove uncoordinated PEI molecules. The functiona- lized nanorods were dispersed in deionized water and taken for phantom MRI imaging. Similarly to NRs, the aqueous sus- pension of the amine coated nanoparticles is also prepared by surface modification with polyethyleneimine (PEI).

A straight- forward synthetic route to IOP-8.8 is as follows: 0.9 g (1 mmol) of iron oleate complex was dissolved in 10 mL of benzyl ether, with the addition of 0.16 mL (0.5 mmol) of oleic acid and 15 mg (0.05 mmol) of sodium oleate. The solution was kept at 120 C for 20 min before reaching reflux and was allowed to react for 1 h before cooling to room temperature. The products were obtained by addition of 50 mL of ethanol and centrifugation at 7000 rpm for 10 min. After being washed with ethanol twice, the precipitate was dispersed in hexane and stored for further use. The preparation of IOP-4.8 and IOP-2.8 is similar to the above procedure except for the quantity of sodium oleate (0.1 and 0.2 mmol, respectively).
The preparation of DMSA-coated nanoparticles was carried out through a ligand exchange process.7 For example, excess DMSA (10 mg) was dissolved in 10 mL of ultrapure water in a three-neck flask, and the as- prepared iron oxide nanoparticles (100 μmol) dissolved in hexane were added to the flask. The solution was then heated to reflux for 2 h before cooling to room temperature. The nanoparticles were obtained at down-layer, suggesting the successful DMSA coating. The obtained water-soluble nanopar- ticles were stored at 4 C.

In a typical experiment, 0.76 g iron- oleate (0.84 mmol), 0.17 g Mn-oleate (0.28 mmol), and 132 l oleic acid (0.41 mmol) were dissolved in 15 mL 1-octadecene at room temperature. The mixture was degassed in vacuum for 30 min and backfilled with argon to remove any low volatile impurities and oxygen at room temperature. After that the reaction solution was heated to reflux with a constant heating rate of 3.3 °C min-1, and kept at that temperature for 1 h. The resultant solution was then cooled to room temperature and mixed with 30 mL isopropanol to precipitate the nanoparticles. The nanoparticles were separated by centrifugation and washed 3 times with ethanol. After washing, the nanoparticles were dissolved in hexane for long term storage at 4 °C.

A one-pot synthetic route of MnxFe3-xO4
nanoparticles (using x = 0.43 as example) is as follows: 0.903 g (1 mmol) of iron oleate (synthesized
in a typical method) and 0.104 g (0.167 mmol) manganese oleate were dissolved in 15mL of
1-octadecene, with the addition of 0.186 mL (0.584 mmol) of oleic acid. The solution was first kept
at 120 °C for 30 min in vacuum to remove air and other impurities then refluxed at 320 °C in N2 for
2 h before cooling to room temperature. The products were separated by centrifugation, washed three
times with ethanol, and dispersed in hexane for further use. The preparation of Fe3O4 nanoparticles is
similar to the procedure without the adding of manganese oleate.
